Award.AwardTitle: Packing and Unpacking the Genome: Single-Molecule Manipulation of Chromatin
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the PIs will use single-molecule optical tweezers to elucidate the structural, mechanical and thermodynamic consequences of biologically-relevant post-translational modifications (PTMs) on the behavior of individual nucleosomes and on chromatin condensation. The fundamental biological significance of the proposed research is that the packaging of DNA into nucleosomes and chromatin, and its modulation by histone modifications and histone H1, are essential aspects of gene regulation in all eukaryotes. Specific objectives of this project include: (1) assemble nucleosomes and chromatin, using histone H4 with prescribed single and multiple site-specific acetylation; (2) compare the behavior of chromatin in the presence of magnesium ions or magnesium ions and linker histone H1, which are key factors regulating condensation, to the behavior of chromatin without these factors; (3) determine accurate free energy differences between the different molecular states encountered, using an intelligent force-stepping protocol; (4) compare the behavior of nucleosomes containing histone H4 with acetylated tails to those containing H4 with mutated tails, that mimic acetylation, revealing the role of charge. Thus, this project will provide observations and measurements needed to create and validate physical models of eukaryotic gene expression.

The broader impacts of this project include: (1) these studies have potential human health benefits, because several diseases, including asthma and a number of cancers, are linked to histone PTMs; (2) by following Yale's Integrated Graduate Program in Physical and Engineering Biology (IGPPEB) and serving as teaching fellows in a novel introductory physics sequence, that seeks to engage life-science undergraduates, the graduate students involved in this project will join a new generation of researcher/teachers, who excel at quantitative approaches, have the biological sophistication to identify and apply their skills to cutting-edge biological problems, and are excited to educate future generations; (3) to encourage an interest in science in the next generation, the PIs will work with Breakthrough New Haven, a high school preparation program for socio-economically disadvantaged students in Grades 7 and 8, to implement hands-on science modules for Breakthrough's summer program, and will host high-school students for summer research projects in their laboratories.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dynamic packaging of DNA into chromatin is a key determinant of gene regulation. Nucleosomes are the basic unit of chromatin, and therefore the accessible states of the nucleosome must be the starting point for mechanistic models regarding these essential regulatory processes. Although the existence of different unwound nucleosome states has been hypothesized and the potential consequences of multiple nucleosome states are far reaching, there have been few studies that probe multiple nucleosome states. This project discovered the existence of two distinct states of the unwound nucleosome, which are accessible at physiological forces and ionic strengths. Which state is preferentially realized depends on force and ionic strength, suggesting possible roles for these states in gene regulation. For example, different histone variants or modifications may facilitate or suppress access to the genetic code by promoting unwinding into one state or the other. It may be anticipated that the two unwound states discovered will be the basis for future models of how gene expression is controled. This project also carried out measurements to characterize how the addition of histone H1 to DNA causes the DNA to spontaneously condense, which is the mechanism by which DNA in sperm is packaged. H1-driven DNA condensation involves a sequence of transitions corresponding to the unwinding of a number of large superhelical turns. From these data, it was possible to determine the H1-DNA complex’s multi-state free energy landscape, in an elegant application of the recently-introduced Crooks’ fluctuation theorem, that enables free energies to be determined from non-equilibrium data. Both measured force-extension and the extracted free energy agree with predictions from a simple theoretical model.

 

Achieving these experimental results required the development of two powerful new methodologies. First, to examine the rate at which nucleosomes unwind lead to the implementation of a novel real-time jump detection and force-clamp method that recognizes the state of a nucleosome – wound or unwound -- and then intelligently adjusts and maintains the force correspondingly. This method enables data collection many times faster than previously, permitting the accurate determination of force-dependent lifetime distributions and reaction rates. Application of this method to unwinding and rewinding the nucleosome inner turn reveals lifetime distributions that are accurately single exponential. These measurements significantly reduce the error in the previously measured rates, and demonstrate the existence of a single, dominant free energy barrier at each force studied. Second, a desire to improve analyses of diffusive motion in the H1-DNA condensation experiments motivated the introduction a suite of novel, unsupervised, system-level, machine-learning-based data analysis and classification methods, that, given a variety of different behaviors within a population of particles undergoing diffusion, (1) recognizes and characterizes different diffusive states within that population of trajectories, and (2) sorts each individual trajectory into its most likely diffusive states. The latest version of these methods is capable of analyzing diffusive behavior, that shows variability from particle to particle and from time to time, to now uncover from a population of trajectories the different possible kinds of diffusive motion that individual particles may undergo, and the transitions among them. As proof-of-principle, fluorescent tracks from a number of proteins diffusing in the cell membrane of living human epithelial cells were analyzed and found to realize six different diffusive states, broadly consistent with biological expectations. Application of this method to DNA binding proteins diffusing in the cell nucleus and binding to and unbinding from chromatin is ongoing. A potentially transformative aspect of this method, once it is fully realized and elaborated, is that, because a particle’s diffusive behavior can be a reporter of its biochemical state, this method may permit us to monitor, characterize, and understand biochemistry in vivo in living cells at the single protein level. It represents a powerful new analysis tool  for studying diffusion of all sorts inside living cells, that will find many applications across biology and the physics of living systems. Finally, four young scientists received training in this project, and have gone on to other academic positions and positions in industry.
